ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



  It is the policy of all Americold facilities to conduct all operations in a safe manner. This policy extends to all employees and contractors at the facility. Americold implements this policy towards chemical and general safety through on-going employee participation, training, written operating procedures, maintenance, inspections, safety committee meetings, and safety reviews/evaluations. These programs are in effect at the facility to prevent the accidental release of ammonia. In the event of an ammonia accident, the facility has an Emergency Action Plan to notify the appropriate authorities and safely evacuate the facility. The facility is coordinated with the local fire department, who will be the facility's emergency responder.





STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The ammonia refrigeration system is installed at the Americold - Lynden facility located at 406 2nd Street Lynden, Washington. The primary business of Americold is to provide refrigerated warehousing and storage for various food products.  





ENGINE ROOM DETAILS

   In order to conduct operations; the facility maintains a refrigeration system containing approximately 50,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia, a regulated substance.  The refrigeration system, consisting of piping, valves, and equipment, cycles ammonia through various physical states (high pressure liquid, low pressure liquid, low pressure vapor, high pressure vapor, and then back to high pressure liquid) in order to provide refrigeration for dock operations, cooler/freezer storage.  Typical operating conditions range from 5" hg on the low pressure side of the system to 150 psig on the high side of the system.  



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



   The Americold - Lynden ammonia refrigeration system has many safety features. Much of the safety of the system is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern t

he operation of the system. For example, the facility operates in accordance with OSHA's Process Safety Management regulation. 



The facility ammonia refrigeration system operates in accordance with many of the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR) guidelines with which specifically outline requirements for the safe operation of the ammonia refrigeration system. These safety features include ammonia sensors in the engine room as well as sensors at each evaporator, and automatic shutdown systems. In addition, the majority of the ammonia equipment is maintained inside the engine room. All pressure vessels are equipped with pressure relief valves that are piped to a common header, equipped with an ammonia sensor, and vent to the ammonia dilution tank and/or vent to atmosphere above the roof.







FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



A review into the accident history of the facility revealed that there have been no recordable accidents to report within the last 5 years.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



The Americold - Lynden facility has an emergency action plan in effect. The Emergency Action Plan (Plan) is detailed in the Emergency Planning and Response section of the PSM/RMP document. This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:



1. To save lives.

2. To minimize and avoid injuries.

3. To protect the environment.

4. To minimize property damage.



The operator of the facility maintains a safety committee whose members are the designated emergency coordinators for the facility. The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility. This Plan was reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM and RMP regulations.



In case of an ammonia emergency, the Americold - Lynden facility plans to evacuate all employees in the facility and alert the

local emergency responders (fire department). The Chief Engineer/Facility Service Manager has coordinated emergency response efforts with the local fire department. Operators at the facility are trained to respond to releases of ammonia in Level B PPE with SCBA. A full team can be provided by the Facility in most circumstances, coordinating with the Local Fire department. Operators will respond to an ammonia release in conjunction with the local Fire Dept. Incident command will be transferred to the Fire Chief upon his arrival.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



The Process Hazards Analysis study and a Facility Inspection, provided mitigation measures to improve safety at the Americold - Lynden facility located at 406 2nd Street Lynden, Washington. The Americold - Lynden safety committee has regular meetings as a continual effort to provide a safe work environment for their employees. These meetings include tracking the following items:



1. Continue to train all employees in the facility safety plan/programs.



2. Continue to have employee involvement in safety plan development.



3. Continue employee involvement through safety team participation.



4. Continue internal and external safety audits/inspections and implement changes as needed.
